The Elder Who Gave a Single Garment
“In the city of Haṁsavatī,
I was a grass-gatherer.
I lived by gathering grass,
And with it I supported my children.
The Victor named Padumuttara,
Who had gone beyond all things,
Having dispelled the darkness,
Appeared as the Leader of the World.
Sitting in my own house,
I thought like this at that time:
‘A Buddha has arisen in the world,
But I have nothing to give.
This is my single garment,
And I have no one to give it to.
The touch of hell is painful,
I will plant a gift.’
Having thought like this,
I delighted in my own mind.
Taking a single garment,
I went to the best of Buddhas.
Having given a single garment,
I made a vow:
‘If you are a Buddha, O Hero,
Deliver me, O Great Sage.’
Padumuttara, the knower of the world,
The receiver of offerings,
Having accepted my gift,
Gave me his blessing.
‘With this one piece of cloth,
with intention and aspiration,
for a hundred thousand aeons,
he will not go to a state of woe.
Thirty-six times he will be the lord of the gods,
